Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Specificity of soluble adenylyl cyclase and regulation by bicarbonate and nucleotides
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this EAGER award, the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program is funding Professor Stephen Sprang of the University of Montana to address fundamental structural, functional and mechanistic questions about the class of soluble adenylyl cyclase (sAC) enzymes. Namely, Professor Sprang and his group will use the tools of x-ray crystallography and mechanistic enzymology to address how sACs sense carbon dioxide and pH and whether they produce previously unrecognized second messengers for biological signal transduction.

Student and research associate co-workers involved in this project will be exposed to cutting edge biophysical techniques at the interface of mechanistic chemistry and structural biology. Additionally, the PI will endeavor to broaden participation through the inclusion of members of groups that are traditionally underrepresented in physical science research.

We set out to study a protein catalyst, or enzyme, called adenylyl cyclase (AC for short) that converts the chemical ATP (adenosine triphosphate) to cyclic AMP (cAMP). ATP is an energy-rich molecule that is used by cells in our bodies as chemical fuel.  cAMP, on the other hand, is a regulator: it binds to a number of different enzymes that control important cellular functions and either activates or inactivates them.  The role of AC in the cell is to produce cAMP, and it does so under the control of proteins that respond to chemical signals from other cells.   There are many forms of AC, but the one we study - AC10 - is different from the rest in that it contains two different modules that bind to ATP.  One of these modules is similar to those found in all ACs. It is the site at which ATP is converted to cAMP.  The other module that binds to ATP does not have a known function.  We think that it may have regulatory activity – to control the function of the catalytic module.  This seems possible because the sequence of amino acids that make up this module is similar to that of a large family of enzymes called AAA+ ATPases that also bind to ATP.  ATP binding causes many of these AAA+ ATPases to assemble into doughnut-shaped structures typically made up of six individual protein molecules. ATP-induced assembly is key to the ability of AAA+ proteins to regulate other enzymes.  We conducted experiments to learn whether the AAA+ ATPase-like domain of AC10 behaves like a regulator.  If so, it would be important because AC10 plays many key roles in animal physiology, like the ability of sperm to fertilize eggs. AC10 may also control the production of ATP in an organ of the cell called the mitochondrion.

In the course of our research, we found that when the AAA+ domain of AC10 binds to ATP, it assembles into aggregates containing at least four AAA+ molecules.  We also found that AAA+ modules very slowly convert ATP to ADP (removing a unit of phosphate from ATP).  We have been working to determine whether AC10’s AAA+ ATPase domain regulates its ability to synthesize cAMP.  In the course of this project, we made a serendipitous, and unrelated discovery.
